Attention Mercer County Residents:

Strong broadband internet access is key in educating our children. Unfortunately, not everyone has access to this resource. Mercer County Better Together (MCBT) is a local non-profit organization that is building a plan to expand broadband internet in Mercer County. This project is led by a local team designed to best represent Mercer County - if you do not have reliable internet service right now, MCBT would love to hear from you! Your perspective will help MCBT build a plan that best serves our children, our families, our businesses and our communities. To learn more or to share your experiences, contact MCBT Executive Director Kyle McEwen via email at kyle@mcbettertogether.org or by phone at (309) 574-3123.

Assistant Business Manager Vacancy

Sherrard School District is seeking to hire an assistant business manager. Major responsibilities include handling payroll, accounts payable and accounts receivable. Responsibilities also include creating government/board reports, operating purchase/invoice systems, maintaining certain personnel records and coordinating insurance, pension, unemployment, IRS and FICA tasks.

Accuracy, honestly, dependability, initiative, cooperativeness and confidentiality are a must. An accounting degree or payroll experience is required. School-related accounting experience is preferred.

Sherrard School District employs 200+ staff members and has a budget exceeding $16 million.

Interested persons should apply online using the district's online application that can be found in the employment section of the website (www.sherrard.us)

It’s Teacher Appreciation Week!

All the employees of Sherrard School District are educators and each one of them deserves our appreciation. This annual recognition looks a little different this year. It will be quieter and there will be less food, but the level of gratitude from the stakeholders is higher than ever.

Over the past couple months, everyone has had to rearrange the way they do education. They had to learn new technology skills, do things out of their comfort zone and continue to work with little insight into where things were going. Through it all, our educators persevere and remain focused. They plan, teach, communicate and lead. They clean, prepare meals, deliver materials, complete important paperwork, and repair things. All of this has been done while social distancing and taking care of the needs and challenges of their own families.

Thank you, Educators! Your work is noticed and it is worthy of honor and celebration!

The idea was to have a free "Little Library" outside SG to allow children and adults to borrow a book, and loan a book.

With the help of daughters, Anabel, 6 and Marily, 2, the Fritch family constructed a Little Library to sit outside Sherrard Grade. It will be installed and ready this week.

“They truly answered and stepped up. SG is very grateful to the Fritch Family for their amazing work and generous donation so all children have materials to read during this trying time, and beyond,” said Fry.

This time last year Sherrard high school students and Winola fourth graders designed, constructed and installed a free little library for Winola Elementary school in Viola.

School Closure Update - March 20

Earlier today, Governor Pritzker issued an executive order requiring residents to “stay at home” beginning Saturday evening. As part of the Governor’s order, he announced that school will remain closed with a new school start date of April 8.

Because of the tighter restrictions, it will now be difficult to reach school officials using the phone. Families are encouraged to email the staff persons individually, or send an email to contactus@sherrard.us.

We have received a lot of positive feedback about the e-learning program. We will continue to provide lessons and activities during the rest of the shutdown. Structure and predictability will help the students maintain emotional health. Please email your child’s teachers if you have questions.

The sack meal program will continue. The number of participants has grown each day. The meals are free and all the students may participate regardless of family income. Email Marla Miller if you would like to sign up. Her email address is millerm@sherrard.us

post_text:
Today during spanish class, Sherrard senior Guin Diehl was surprised with the Chancellor’s Scholarship for four years of tuition and fees to the University of Wisconsin-Platteville. Only 10 were chosen out of almost 400 applicants, according to Chris Kerkenbush, Regional Admission Advisor at University of Wisconsin-Platteville.

“I’m really shocked. I’m so happy right now... really excited,” said Diehl. She plans to double major in math, with an emphasis in high school education, and music.

“I want to be a math teacher, I also want to write music on the side - and if I can, I also want to teach college,” she said.

Kerkenbush said a committee of eight filters the applicants, “We chose based on location, diversity, all around devotion to school, her grades, community service - her essay was the key part.”

“It’s a huge accomplishment. The Chancellor (Dennis J. Shields) reviews all of them… She should be very honored.” She said the scholarship totals around $40,000 over the course of four years.

Diehl's parents are Mike and Jen Diehl of New Windsor, her brother is Mike, Jr.

U.S. Army Private First Class Macy Wolford, spoke to Mrs. Strandgard’s fourth grade class this morning at Sherrard Elementary School. Wolford is a 2019 Sherrard graduate. She left for army basic training at Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri in August - her former high school Volleyball Coach, Erica Slattery, arranged for her daughter Laney’s fourth grade class to write her letters of encouragement.

To their surprise - she hand wrote a letter back to each of the 22 students - using her 30 minutes of personal time each evening in October and November.

She graduated from training at the end of January, and she was happy to personally thank the class, talk about her experience, and answer their questions.

She said receiving the kids letters meant a lot to her. “Very cute, very motivational… I loved it.”

She thanked the class, “We struggle with motivation. It’s a lot of hard work and you can’t give up on yourself, otherwise you’ll fail.”

**Matherville Spotlight**

Sanya Boucher, School Nurse, attended Pella Community High School in the Des Moines Area, and Community College Faith Baptist Bible College. She received her nursing degree from University of Illinois Chicago School Nursing Certification

She spent 8 years in hospital nursing med/surg and peds, and she’s now in her 21’st year as School Nurse at Matherville Intermediate and the Junior/Senior high school.

Her favorite book is The Secret Garden by Frances Hodgson Burnett.

“I am married to Alan Boucher, the superintendent. I love snow days and he hates snow days. They say opposites attract.”

Mrs. and Mr. Boucher have four children, (all married) and six grandchildren.

“We love spending time with family and camping. We hope to spend more time camping in retirement.”

Her favorite quote is, "You can't educate people if they're not healthy and you certainly can't keep them healthy if they're not educated." D. Joycelyn Elders (15th Surgeon General of the U.S.A.)

Winola Elementary students enjoyed Star Lab this week. The inflatable classroom is set up in the library around this time each year.

Students learned about the stars and constellations in the night sky.

Second grade teacher Melanie Flickinger said she has had high school students who told her they were able to answer ACT questions based on information they learned during Star Labs.

"It's so interesting, it's something different. We can never stop teaching star lab - and who knows which one of these students might become part of NASA, or an astronaut. It's inspirational to include another career for kids to explore," she said.

Winola secures the Star Lab through the Rock Island County Regional Office of Education for one week each winter. They first started using it in the early 1990's.

Jill Bennin, District Media Specialist, graduated from Glenbard East High School then received her Bachelor's in English Education from Augustana College, and a Master’s degree in Reading at Western Illinois University. She has a certificate in School Librarianship from Illinois State University.

This is her 20th year, both in education and in the Sherrard School District. She started in the 2000- 2001 school year as a Junior High English teacher.

“I taught 5 years of junior high English, 7 years total of high school English (divided by another position), 3 years as a District Reading Specialist, and 5 1/2 years as the District Library Media Specialist,” said Bennin.

When asked her favorite book, she said, “I have a lot of favorite books, one of my favorites from the Matherville library collection is Princess X.”
